com.ojcoleman.europa.configurable

Class ConfigurableBase

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.ojcoleman.europa.configurable.Observable
      • com.ojcoleman.europa.configurable.ConfigurableBase
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Stringable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ComponentBase, NNConfig, Parallel, ParametrisedGeneType, PrototypeBase, VectorMetadata, VectorMetadata.ElementDefaults

    public class ConfigurableBase
extends Observable
implements Stringable

    A base class for classes that are configurable via a JSON configuration file.

    Parameter Fields
    Fields in a ConfigurableBase may be marked as user configurable using the Parameter annotation. For example: \@Parameter (description="My first parameter.", defaultValue="100") protected int myParam1; \@Parameter (description="My second parameter.", optional=true) private String myParam2; And corresponding JSON: "myConfigurable": { "myParam1: 123, "myParam2: "Ests are the best", ... } When the ConfigurableBase is instantiated the field will be assigned the value specified in the JSON configuration file, or the default value if a default value has been set. Parameter fields may be of the following types:

    • Any of the primitive types;
    • Any class that has a constructor accepting a single String argument (in which case the string value specified in the configuration file is passed to this constructor);
    • Any class that has a constructor accepting a single JsonValue argument (in which case the JSON value specified in the configuration file is passed to this constructor);
    • Enum (in which case the configuration should specify the name of the specific enum);
    • Class (in which case the configuration should specify the canonical class name);
        • Parameter fields may be arrays, in which case the configuration for it should be an array, for example: \@Parameter (description="My array parameter.") protected Class[] myClasses; and corresponding JSON: { "myClasses": [ "my.Class1", "my.sub.Class2", "java.lang.Double" ] }

        Sub-classes may not contain fields with the same name.

        Note: setting an initial value for a Parameter field will prevent the fields value being set via a configuration. This is because Java processes initial field values after calling the super-class's constructor. For more information see http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8843825/why-are-member-objects-initialized-after-the-super-classs-constructor

        ConfigurableBase Fields
        If a ConfigurableBase has a field whose type extends ConfigurableBase and is annotated with Configurable or Prototype, then it will be instantiated hierarchically. This supports the getConfiguration(boolean) method (and so the "--printConfig" command line argument for Main).

        Run-time Sub-class Specification
        The user configuration may specify the class of the ConfigurableBase. This class must be a sub-class of the original class. For example if one wished to customise the behaviour of a Component (which extends ConfigurableBase), say DefaultEvolver, then a custom class that extends DefaultEvolver can be created, and the (full canonical) class name specified in the configuration file for the Component. For example: "myConfigurable": { "class": "my.custom.Class1", "myParam: 123, ... }

    Author:
    O. J. Coleman

    • Field Detail

      • isDummy

        Indicates that this instance is a dummy, most likely being used for printing out configuration options.

      • id

        public final long id
        A unique ID for this instance.

      • idFactory

        protected IDFactory idFactory
        Factory used to generate unique IDs. This is passed from Configurable to sub-Configurable and so on as initialisation proceeds hierarchically.

    • Constructor Detail

      • ConfigurableBase

        public ConfigurableBase(Configuration config)
        Creates and configures this ConfigurableBase with the given configuration. Sub-classes must implement a constructor accepting the same parameters and call super(config). Overriding implementations of this constructor should return after calling super() if null is provided (null is used to create dummy instances when printing the available default configuration options).
        Parameters:
        config - The configuration for this ConfigurableBase.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - If an error occurred setting parameter field values.

      • ConfigurableBase

        public ConfigurableBase(ConfigurableBase configurable)
        Creates a copy of the given ConfigurableBase. The copy is essentially a shallow copy (except for id): calls to getSingleton(Class) on the copy and the original will return exactly the same result. The rationale for this behaviour is that this copy constructor is primarily intended to support the Prototype#Prototype(PrototypeBase) copy constructor, which is intended to efficiently create many copies of the same prototype object. Performing deep copies of the contained singleton and prototype objects and associated internal supporting data structures would incur a generally undesirable and unnecessary performance cost.
        Parameters:
        configurable - The ConfigurableBase to create a copy of.

      • ConfigurableBase

        public ConfigurableBase()
        Creates an unconfigured ConfigurableBase. This is useful when a sub-class may be instantiated programmatically.

    • Method Detail

      • getSuperClasses

        protected java.util.List<java.lang.Class<?>> getSuperClasses()
        Gets a list containing this class and all its super-classes up to the parent ConfigurableBase. The list is ordered from super to this class.

      • newGenericInstance

        public <T> T newGenericInstance(java.lang.Class<T> clazz)
                     throws java.lang.RuntimeException
        Instantiates and returns a new instance of the specified Class. If many instances will be created then Prototypes should be used, see #newInstance(Class). This is because newGenericInstance uses Java's reflection API to instantiate new instances, which is relatively slow.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if there is no constructor in clazz taking no arguments.
        NewInstanceConstructorException - if an exception occurred in the constructor for clazz. The underlying cause Exception is wrapped in the NewInstanceConstructorException.
        java.lang.RuntimeException - if some other Exception occurred, such as a SecurityException . These are wrapped up in "RuntimeException" because if any of them occurs it's probably a fatal error, so there's little point forcing callers to add try-catch statements (but of course they still may if they wish to), it might as well bubble up to the top.
        See Also:
        #newInstance(Class), getSingleton(Class)

      • getSingleton

        public <T> T getSingleton(java.lang.Class<T> clazz)
               throws java.lang.RuntimeException
        Convenience method to handle the generation and access of singletons. The first call to this method specifying some specific class will generate a new instance of that class. Subsequent calls specifying the same class will return this instance. This is useful when a configuration must specify the class for some object in the system that should or need not be a ConfigurableBase or based on a Prototype (see #newInstance(Class)). Care must be taken to ensure that it has a constructor no arguments.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if there is no constructor in clazz taking no arguments.
        NewInstanceConstructorException - if an exception occurred in the constructor for clazz. The underlying cause Exception is wrapped in the NewInstanceConstructorException.
        java.lang.RuntimeException - if some other Exception occurred, such as a SecurityException . These are wrapped up in "RuntimeException" because if any of them occurs it's probably a fatal error, so there's little point forcing callers to add try-catch statements (but of course they still may if they wish to), it might as well bubble up to the top.
        See Also:
        #newInstance(Class), newGenericInstance(Class)

      • getStringableMap

        public void getStringableMap(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> map)
        Description copied from interface: Stringable

        Specified by:

        Parameters:
